nodes.text: When a person is induced to state or perform something contrary to a private opinion, cognitive dissonance causes a change in private opinion toward the stated behavior, and this change is larger when the external inducement beyond the minimum is smaller

Theory of cognitive dissonance: inconsistency between cognitions (private belief and public statement) creates psychological dissonance which is a function of dissonances divided by dissonances plus consonances and can be reduced by changing private belief to match public statement
Specific prediction derived from the theory: subjects paid larger rewards to make a counter-attitudinal statement will show less subsequent opinion change than subjects paid minimal sufficient reward

Laboratory experiment manipulated level of external inducement with three conditions: Control (no request to lie), One Dollar payment, and Twenty Dollars payment; subjects performed boring tasks and were asked to tell a waiting person the tasks were enjoyable; private opinions measured later by blind interviewer

Overall experimental conclusion: results support the cognitive dissonance prediction that induced counter-attitudinal behavior produces opinion change and that larger external reward beyond minimum reduces that change

Prior studies (Janis and King) found that improvising a speech for a contrary position produced private opinion change toward the speech, explained previously by mental rehearsal and argument generation
Kelman reported that larger rewards produced less opinion change than smaller rewards but his data were inconclusive due to self-selection and compliance variability
Participants: 71 male introductory psychology students required to participate as subjects; final analyzed sample was 60 (20 per condition) after excluding 11 for suspicion, refusal, or disclosure

Procedure details: subjects did two repetitive half-hour tasks designed to be boring, then either were asked to tell a waiting student the tasks were fun (Control not asked), were paid one dollar or twenty dollars to do so, conversation was covertly tape recorded, and later the true purpose was revealed and money returned

Dependent measures: blind interviewer asked four questions after the experiment rating enjoyment of tasks, how much learned, scientific importance, and desire to participate again using numeric scales
Exclusions and reasons: 11 subjects excluded because they were suspicious about payment, disclosed being hired, refused pay, or tried to contact the confederate; these were run but not analyzed

Primary result on enjoyment: One Dollar group rated tasks as significantly more enjoyable (mean +1.35) than Control (mean -0.45), Twenty Dollar group rated near Control (-0.05); difference One Dollar vs Twenty Dollar significant, supporting dissonance prediction

Secondary results: desire to participate in similar experiment showed same directional pattern as enjoyment (One Dollar higher than Control and Twenty Dollar) but weaker significance; perceived scientific importance slightly higher in One Dollar than Twenty Dollar with marginal significance; learning showed no differences across conditions

Alternative explanation test: taped conversations were transcribed and rated blind on content, persuasiveness, and time on topic; ratings showed no evidence that One Dollar subjects rehearsed or behaved more convincingly than Twenty Dollar subjects, disconfirming rehearsal/self-persuasion account

Overall inference: forced compliance produced opinion change consistent with cognitive dissonance theory and change magnitude inversely related to excess external justification (smaller reward produced greater attitude change)
